message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decreased serum C3 level and elevated anti-DNAse B titer points towards post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. On renal biopsy, we would most likely see large, hypercellular glomeruli on light microscopy. The other options are associated with other types of renal diseases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), which is characterized by large, hypercellular glomeruli on light microscopy. Option B is seen in IgA nephropathy, option C is seen in membranous nephropathy, and option D is seen in Goodpasture syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory results suggest post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). On renal biopsy, PSGN is characterized by the presence of large, hypercellular glomeruli on light microscopy. Polyclonal IgA deposition is associated with IgA nephropathy, immune complex deposits with a “spike and dome” appearance on electron microscopy is associated with membranous nephropathy, and antibodies to GBM resulting in a linear immunofluorescence pattern is associated with Goodpasture’s syndrome, which are not commonly associated with PSGN.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), which is characterized by large, hypercellular glomeruli on light microscopy. The other options are not associated with PSGN. Polyclonal IgA deposition is seen in IgA nephropathy, immune complex deposits with a "spike and dome" appearance are seen in membranous nephropathy, and antibodies to GBM resulting in a linear immunofluorescence pattern are seen in Goodpasture's syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), which is associated with decreased serum C3 level and elevated anti-DNAse B titer. On renal biopsy, PSGN typically shows large, hypercellular glomeruli on light microscopy. The other options are associated with different types of glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decreased serum C3 level and elevated anti-DNAse B titer suggest a post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. On renal biopsy, large, hypercellular glomeruli are typically seen, indicating proliferative glomerulonephritis. Option (B) is more likely to indicate IgA nephropathy, (C) suggests membranous nephropathy or lupus nephritis, and (D) suggests Goodpasture syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decreased serum C3 level and elevated anti-DNAse B titer suggest poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. The characteristic finding on renal biopsy is large, hypercellular glomeruli on light microscopy. Polyclonal IgA deposition on immunofluorescence is seen in IgA nephropathy. Immune complex deposits with a "spike and dome" appearance on electron microscopy is seen in membranous nephropathy. Antibodies to GBM resulting in a linear immunofluorescence pattern is seen in Goodpasture syndrome.

The characteristic finding on renal biopsy is large, hypercellular glomeruli on light microscopy. Polyclonal IgA deposition is seen in IgA nephropathy, immune complex deposits with a “spike and dome” appearance on electron microscopy is seen in membranous nephropathy, and linear immunofluorescence pattern is seen in Goodpasture syndrome.

The clinical presentation and laboratory results suggest post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), which is characterized by large, hypercellular glomeruli on light microscopy. Polyclonal IgA deposition is seen in IgA nephropathy, immune complex deposits with a "spike and dome" appearance are seen in membranous nephropathy, and antibodies to GBM resulting in a linear immunofluorescence pattern are seen in Goodpasture syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which is characterized by a decreased serum C3 level and an elevated anti-DNAse B titer. On renal biopsy, large, hypercellular glomeruli on light microscopy are expected findings in this type of glomerulonephritis. Polyclonal IgA deposition is seen in IgA nephropathy, immune complex deposits with a "spike and dome" appearance are seen in membranous nephropathy, and linear immunofluorescence pattern is seen in Goodpasture syndrome.
